quote: Dax? I can't believe it...

I can hardly believe it myself.    But I'm Dax... I mean, I'm not    Jadzia Dax. I'm Ezri Dax. But I    have all of Jadzia's memories.    Not to mention Lela's, Tobin's,    Emony's, Audrid's, Joran's,    Curzon's...        Am I forgetting anyone?
Torias?

Right. You're probably asking    yourself -- who is this person?    How did she get the Dax symbiont?    Do I even want another Dax in my    life? Does she always talk this    much? These are all good    questions.        I wish I had good answers.
The answers can wait. Right now,    I'm just glad to see you.
(fighting back the     tears)    Really? That's so nice of you to    say.
I'm not usually this emotional.    Must be the Emony in me.        At least I think it's Emony...    Hi, Jake.
Hi.
You seem taller. Or am I    shorter?        You know, none of this is my    fault. I never asked to be    joined.
Then how'd you end up with the    symbiont?
It was an accident.
Some accident.

I was on the Destiny when the Dax    symbiont was brought on board to    be taken back to Trill. Halfway    through the trip, it took a turn    for the worse and had to be    placed in a host immediately.
And you were the only Trill on    board.

I laid down on the operating    table as one person and woke up a    different person... actually,    eight different people. I wasn't    prepared for any of it. You're    supposed to go through years of    training and preparation before    being joined. All I got was a    fifteen minute lecture from the    ships's surgeon. And he wasn't    even a Trill.
I'm starting to see the problem.
I can't tell you how much better    I feel... being here with you,    Ben.
What about the Symbiosis    Institute? Wasn't there anything    they could do for you?
I did meet with the Evaluation    Board several times.
And?

They gave me some books to    read... some counseling... but    once the host and the symbiont    are joined, there's really not    much they can do.         My parents, my friends, my    crewmates... it's like they don't    know me anymore -- which is    understandable since I hardly    know myself.         That's why I took a leave of    absence and came here. If anyone    can help me through this, it's    you.
I'll do all I can, but the truth    is, we're leaving for Tyree...
Fine. I'll come with you.
You don't even know why we're   going.
It doesn't matter.
When do we leave?
Today.
Great. It'll be like old times.        Except different.

Jadzia Dax Vond Shoo-vwee Dun Mahh-   kekh Huh-Koo-Vahm Jeh Yin-Moj Mah-   Mukh. Sto-vo-kor Pah-Dahkh-tin Baht-   leh el-eegh-cha yay-moj. (We dedicate    this mission and our lives to the    memory of a great warrior, Jadzia Dax.    Through our victory, she will enter    the sacred halls of Sto-vo-kor.)
Quark, son of Keldar, reporting for --
Did I come at a bad time?
What are you doing here, Quark?
Same thing you are. I'm    volunteering for this mission.
Why? You're a bartender, not a    warrior.

True, but I loved Jadzia as much    as anyone in this room.        With maybe one or two    exceptions...    (getting back to the     point)    And I'm willing to pledge my life    to see that she gets into Sto-vo-kor.
(pleased with     Quark's words)    Perhaps there is some Klingon in    you after all.
I wouldn't go that far.    So why all the cutlery?
We shed our blood to prove we are    not frightened of death.
Can't you just take my word for    it?
Oww! That hurts.
It's supposed to hurt.
YuWee-modge. Baht-leh-modge.    Yay-Dodge. (Blood. Honor.    Glory.)
This is so embarrassing.
Don't worry about it. It's not    your fault.
I'm a trained Starfleet officer.    I have no business getting space    sick. But ever since I was given    the symbiont, warp speed makes me    a little queasy.
A little queasy... ?
The main thing is that the control    panel's all cleaned up... so if    one of you would like to get back    into the pilot's seat, it would    sure make me feel better.
Not that I don't trust the    computer.
You just prefer the human touch.
That's why you won't find a food    replicator anywhere in my    restaurant.
Please -- let's not talk about    food.
Do you need to lie down?
I'm fine, really.
Well, it's time for my nap.
You're sure you're all right?
But I wish I could stop thinking    about Torias.
Torias Dax? He was one of your    previous hosts, wasn't he?
He died in a shuttle accident.    I still remember those last few    seconds before the crash...        Maybe I don't belong in Starfleet    anymore...        Aren't you glad I came along?
Actually, I am.    (with a glance over     to his father)    My dad seems a lot happier since    you showed up.
One iced raktajino.
I know you've been worried about    your father, Jake... but he's    going to be all right.
What makes you so sure?
Because I've known him a long    time. Besides, it's my job to    know these things. I'm a ship's    counselor -- actually, an    assistant ship's counselor.
You're a therapist?
Is it that surprising?
A little.
You know I wasn't always so...    confused. Before I was joined I    was considered a very promising    young officer.
That's horrible. I hate    raktajino.
Then why'd you order it?
Because...    (trying to sort it     out)    Curzon liked it...
So did Jadzia.
Well, I don't. I have to learn    to control some of these urges.
I want you to know, colonel, I'm    as outraged as you are.
The Romulans have no business    placing weapons on Derna.
I'm glad we're in agreement. So    what do you suggest we do about    it?
The Federation has already sent a    strong protest to the Romulan    Senate condemning their action.
That's a start. What happens   next?
They've already issued a formal    protest of our protest.        Politics.
You still haven't answered my    question.
Don't worry, colonel.    Eventually, the Romulans will    remove those weapons.
When? Are we talking days,    weeks, months?
I don't know -- but it will    happen.
Now you're starting to sound like    a politician, admiral.
Maybe so.

But facts are facts, colonel.    There's no way the Bajorans are    going to drive the Romulans off    Derna. Not without help, anyway.    And the Federation isn't going to    provide that help. Not now.        Is that clear?
We're just not as important to    the war effort as the Romulans.
That's a harsh way to put it.
The truth often is.
I really would like to help you,    colonel, but my hands are tied.
Well, luckily, mine aren't.
Meaning what?
Our scans show that the weapons    aren't fully operational yet.    They're still missing launch    sequencers. I'm going to make    sure those sequencers never reach    Derna.
How?
I'll set up a blockade.
Colonel, if you do that, you're    going to have a fight on your    hands... a fight you can't win.
We've entered orbit. Prepare to    beam down.
Why can't we use the ship's    scanners to find the Orb?
There's too much ionization in    the atmosphere. It'll interfere    with our sensors.
You sure you don't want to stay    here and wait for us?
And miss all the excitement? Not    a chance.
All right. But make sure you're    carrying plenty of water packs.         That goes for you, too. It's dry    down there...
Doctor Wykoff, please report to    Isolation Ward Four.
Doctor Wykoff, to Isolation Ward   Four. Immediately.
Did you hear that?
Hear what?
Forget it.
(looking at a     tricorder)    If there's an Orb buried around    here, my tricorder's not picking    it up.
scene: 15   EXT. THE DESERT OF TYREE - DAY (OPTICAL) (LOCATION)

quote: It's out there someplace... I    know it. That's why the Prophets    sent me here...
scene: 15   EXT. THE DESERT OF TYREE - DAY (OPTICAL) (LOCATION)

quote: Did they give you any hint which    way we should go?
scene: 15   EXT. THE DESERT OF TYREE - DAY (OPTICAL) (LOCATION)

quote: That way.
scene: 15   EXT. THE DESERT OF TYREE - DAY (OPTICAL) (LOCATION)

quote: The Prophets have spoken.
scene: 15   EXT. THE DESERT OF TYREE - DAY (OPTICAL) (LOCATION)

quote: I hope he heard them right.
scene: 15   EXT. THE DESERT OF TYREE - DAY (OPTICAL) (LOCATION)

quote: -- once we're close enough, we    can fire an EM pulse at the sun.
The sun? I thought we were    trying to destroy a shipyard.
We are.
Do you understand what he's    talking about?
Always.
Then you explain it.
We're going to fly toward the    molten heart of the sun, so close    that our ship will glow like a    flaming comet.
Hopefully, we won't have to get    that close...
Just close enough to trigger a    solar plasma ejection.
The explosion should incinerate    anything within a hundred million    kilometers.
Including the shipyard.
It will be a glorious firestorm    that will illuminate the gates of    Sto-vo-kor itself and provide a    fitting welcome for Jadzia.
The things we do for love
Did you see that?
See what?
The way he glared at me.
He always glares at you.
Well I'm sick of it. We're    risking our lives to help Jadzia    get into Sto-vo-kor. The very    least Worf could do is show us    some appreciation. I mean is it    so hard to say "thank you?"
Thank you.
Nice try, doctor, but I want to    hear it from him.
Quark -- don't do this...
(building up a head     of steam)    Do what?        All I'm asking for are two little    words...
Be quiet.
That's two words all right. Just    not the two I was hoping for.
Why should I feel any gratitude    toward you? I owe you nothing.

You're not here to help Jadzia    get into Sto-vo-kor -- you're    here because you wish to convince    yourselves that you were worthy    of her.        But the truth is, none of you    could ever hope to be worthy of    Jadzia Dax or even understand the    kind of woman she was.        It's you who should be thanking    me, Ferengi.
For allowing you to come on this   mission and pay honor to her   memory.
(eyes straight     ahead)    I wish you'd stop doing that.
Doing what?
Looking at me like you expect me    to keel over any second.
You'll probably end up carrying    me before this is over.
You're damn right.        But I'll tell you one thing... if    there's a hell, I bet it feels a    lot like this.
Think we're getting close?
I have no idea.
(trying to take it     in stride)    But we're headed in the right    direction?
I hope so.
Audrid loved to walk. Of course,    she preferred the woods... nice    shady glens, cool breezes, cold    streams...
What are you trying to say, Dax?
We've been keeping a pretty fast    pace... it might be a good idea    to give your father and Jake a    chance to rest.
If anyone needs to take a break,    they can go back to the runabout.
I think we should stick together.
Fine. But we're not stopping.
Are you sure that's wise?
How're you doing back there, Dad?
Never better.
... it's only a matter of time    before we break through the enemy    lines.
Once that happens, we can drive    the Federation-Romulan Alliance    out of Cardassian territory.
A little more kanar?
Please.
To victory.        On all fronts.
Damar, have you seen the latest --
Weyoun, this is Siana. We met    last night at the dinner honoring    Legate Hovat.
Damar, you and I have things to    discuss. Things your "guest"    doesn't want to hear.
And why's that?
Because if she does, I'll be    forced to have her executed.
I really should be going.
Until tonight.
What a pleasant woman.
It's imperative that we increase    production at the Monac shipyard.    We need more assault ships to    retake the Chin'toka system.
Damar... are you listening to me?
Increase production... yes, I    heard you. By how much?
Fifteen percent would be ideal.
That won't be easy.
I'm sure you'll find a way.    You're very resourceful.
A blockade? How many ships are    we talking about?
Twelve impulse ships. That's all    the Council of Ministers could    spare right now.
How effective do you think those    twelve ships will be against even    one Romulan warbird?
You sound like Admiral Ross.
I was hoping our relationship was    going to be a long and happy one.
But I suppose I'm willing to   settle for short and exciting.
What's that supposed to mean?
I take it you're going to be    commanding the blockade?
That's right.
Well, then I'm going to be there    with you.
You don't have to do that.
Yes, I do.
Well, I wouldn't start writing    our epitaphs just yet...
All right, I'll wait until the    first wave of Romulan ships    decide to run the blockade.
Don't worry, I don't intend to    get into a firefight with a    squadron of Romulan warbirds.
You mean you're bluffing?
If the Romulans fire on us, it'll    jeopardize their Alliance with    the Federation. I'm hoping    that's a risk they won't want to    take.
And I'm hoping they don't call    your bluff.
Grandpa -- you sure you don't    want to go up to the runabout?
We started this together, we'll    finish it together. I owe it to    Ben.
Doctor Wykoff.
scene: 38   EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE DESERT - DAY

quote: Please come to Isolation Ward    Four immediately. Doctor    Wycoff...
scene: 38   EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE DESERT - DAY

quote: To Isolation Ward Four.
scene: 38   EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE DESERT - DAY

quote: Benjamin.
scene: 38   EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE DESERT - DAY

quote: Is this it?
scene: 38   EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE DESERT - DAY

quote: I think so.
scene: 38   EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE DESERT - DAY

quote: Benjamin, that's not good enough.
scene: 38   EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE DESERT - DAY

quote: Ben...
scene: 38   EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE DESERT - DAY

quote: Are you listening to me?
scene: 38   EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE DESERT - DAY

quote: There.
scene: 41C  INT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT (FROM "IMAGE IN THE SAND")

quote: Where?
scene: 41C  INT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT (FROM "IMAGE IN THE SAND")

quote: That's where we start digging.
scene: 41C  INT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT (FROM "IMAGE IN THE SAND")

quote: Why there?       I wasn't aiming at anything.
scene: 41C  INT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT (FROM "IMAGE IN THE SAND")

quote: Ben, maybe my memories are    playing tricks on me... but were    you always this strange?
scene: 41C  INT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT (FROM "IMAGE IN THE SAND")

quote: Ship's Log, Stardate 52152.6.    We've set up a blockade around    Derna. So far, no Romulan ships    have tried to challenge us.
"Kiss me Deadly"... interesting    title.
And the book isn't bad either. I    think you'll enjoy it.
I'm sure I will... but is this    really the right time to start    reading a book?
Maybe not, but I know how much    you hate all this waiting.    Besides, Mike Hammer has certain    qualities you'll appreciate... I    think.
Such as?
He's as tough as they come and    he hates waiting almost as much    as you do.
I like him already.
Colonel, there's a priority one    transmission from Deep Space    Nine. It's Admiral Ross.
Put him through.
Colonel... Senator Cretak has    just informed me that four    Romulan warbirds are on their way    to Derna.
They'll be arriving in eight    hours with much-needed medical    supplies for the hospital    complex.
Since when did the Romulans start    using warbirds to deliver medical    supplies?
We want to make sure they arrive    safely.
If they try to make it past the    blockade, they're not going to    arrive at all.
That kind of talk isn't going to    help matters, colonel. I would    think you'd want to avoid a    confrontation -- not provoke one.
I wouldn't call those Romulan    ships a peace offering.

(with a disapproving     glance at Cretak)    I wasn't exactly happy to hear    about them either.        We only have a few hours to reach    some kind of a compromise. After    that, people are going to start    dying.
You can talk about compromise all    you want. But any ship    attempting to break through the    blockade will be fired on.
Colonel, do you seriously believe    that your antiquated collection    of impulse ships stand a chance    against our warbirds?
We'll find out soon enough, won't    we?
How'd I do?
Mike Hammer would've been proud.
You're concerned.
Aren't you?
Not really. The colonel is    brave woman, but she's not    stupid. She's bluffing.
Here, Grandpa.
Doctor Wykoff... please come to   Isolation Ward Four. Doctor   Wykoff to Isolation Ward Four.
I wish he'd get there.
Who?
Doctor Wykoff. They're waiting    for him at the isolation ward.
You have definitely gotten    stranger.
What about me, Worf? Would you    rather I hadn't come on this    mission either?
That's not what I'm saying. With    you, it is different... you are a    Klingon -- Jadzia was a member of    your House.
And these men were her friends.    They honor her with their    presence.
(to O'Brien and    Bashir)   Gagh for breakfast, gagh for   lunch, gagh for dinner... am I   the only one who thinks Klingon   menus need to have more variety?
You want to complain about the   gagh, that's fine with me.
But next time, don't complain in   the mess hall when we're sitting   at a table surrounded by a dozen   Klingons.
All right, all right... I get the point.
Good.
But I'm telling you, I think some    of those Klingons agreed with me.
Look, Worf -- if this has    anything to do with what happened    in the mess hall...
It doesn't.
What's the matter? Come up with    a few more insults to throw at    us?
(trying to control    his temper)   Shut up, Ferengi. I wish to   apologize.
I'm listening.
I know Jadzia meant a great deal    to all of you.        And you meant a great deal to her    as well.

Many times... over dinner, when    we discussed our day...        Jadzia would repeat something    amusing that you had said to    her...       ... or describe in endless detail    the intricacies of some new    scheme of yours...        She often talked about you both.    It seemed that even when we were    alone together... one of you was    always with us.
I get it! You were jealous --    because she liked us better than    you.
Would you please be quiet, Quark.
Jadzia was my wife... my    Par'machkai. I did not like    having to share her affections.
That's why you didn't want us to    come on this mission... you    wanted to get her into Sto-vo-kor    without our help.
It was to be my gift to her.
Go on...
There's nothing more to say.    Except... I'm pleased you're here.
I don't think I've ever seen Worf    apologize to anyone.
I don't know about you, but I was    hoping for something a little    more... intriguing.
Such as?
You know... that Jadzia used to    talk about me in her sleep... or    wanted to name her first child    after me...
Chief --
The Monac shipyard. An    impressive sight...
It's certainly big.
Display our target.
Looks hot.
I would not have it any other   way.
Neither would I.
Dad, what is it? Have you found   something?
Stay back.
What are you going to do?
Open it.
Mister Russell -- put it down.
Benjamin -- what's wrong?   Benjamin --
I said, put down the pencil.
Put it down, Mister Russell.
But I haven't finished my story.    Captain Sisko has found the Orb    of the Emissary...
But he hasn't opened it yet.
Mister Russell, you promised not    to write on the walls...
No one will give me any paper...
I thought we had agreed you    weren't going to write at all...    that you needed to rest.
I don't want to rest. I want to    tell my stories.
You were doing so well, Benny.    Making real progress. We were    all so proud of you.
I want to go home. I don't    belong here.
And we're going to send you    home... as soon as you're well.
I feel fine.
But you're not fine. People who    are fine don't write on walls.
Then give me a typewriter.
You're not listening. The    stories have to stop. They're    too dangerous...
Dangerous? To whom?
To you. This world you've    created... Deep Space Nine,    Captain Sisko, Kira and all the    others... none of it is real.
It is to me. If I don't finish    my story... if Sisko doesn't open    the Orb box... he can't contact    the Prophets...

It doesn't matter, Benny -- the    Prophets don't exist either.    They're all figments of your    imagination. Get rid of them...    it's the only way you'll ever get    well...        Now give me the pencil, Benny.
But my story...
It's over. Let it go.
Benjamin!
What are you waiting for? Open    it. That's why we came here,    right?
He can't hear you
Jake!
Ship's Log, Supplemental.   Senator Cretak said that the   Romulan warbirds would be here   in eight hours. She was wrong.   They're two hours early.
They'll be in weapons range in    eight minutes.
(to a Bajoran    Crewman)   Open a channel.
Go ahead.
This is Colonel Kira of the    Bajoran Militia. Any ship that    comes within transporter range of    Derna will be considered hostile    and fired upon.
They're not responding.
Kira to all Bajoran ships.    Prepare to engage.
Sir -- Admiral Ross is asking to    speak to you.
Put him through.
Colonel, I'm appealing to you one    last time to end this blockade.
You know I can't do that,    admiral.

Be aware, that I'm authorized to    use whatever force is necessary    to see that our medical supplies    reach their destination.         However, I'm also authorized to    seek a negotiated settlement...
My government has made its    position quite clear. There will    be no negotiations of any kind as    long as there are Romulan weapons    on Derna.
Damn it, colonel -- if you open    fire on those ships, we all lose.    The only way to beat the Dominion    is to keep our Alliance intact.
Besides, I would hate to see you    throw your life away.
Your concern is touching,    senator. But I'm not dead yet.
At least not for another six    minutes.
You still think she's going to    back down?
She has to... because I'm not.
Take me out of the oven, Moogie.    I'm cooked.
General, I've found it -- a    magnetic instability near the    sun's equator.
Excellent. Let's trigger the    solar eruption, and get out of    here.
It's not that simple. We have to    make sure that the eruption has    the right trajectory to destroy    the shipyard.
And how do we do that?
We have to get closer. Much    closer.
He's right.
Sto-vo-kor... here we come.
Take it, Benny.
What for?
I'm offering you an opportunity    few people ever get... you can    wipe away all your mistakes.
You want me to paint over my    story?
They're just words... meaningless    words that no one cares about.    Get rid of them and you can walk    out of here a free man.
Go ahead. Save yourself.
Got to cover it up... bury it...
Benjamin! What are you doing?
It's for your own good, Benny.    Wipe away the words. Destroy    them before they destroy you.
Ben -- stop!
The Romulans have powered their    weapons. I think they're calling    your bluff.
Auxiliary power to forward    shields.        Kira to all ships. Hold your   positions.
Nerys... if you're going to end    this, I suggest you do it now.
Time to fold, colonel...
Damn it.       We're ready, general.
Decloak and prepare to fire...       ... on Worf's command.
Fire!
It didn't work...
Oh, well -- we tried. Time to    go.
No, not until we complete our    mission.
We need to increase the magnetic    gradient... I'll recalibrate the    deflector.
We might not have time. Three    Jem'Hadar ships are approaching    bearing zero-zero-five mark one-   nine-zero.
I suggest you work quickly,    Chief.
No!
Get out of my way...
You came here to find the    Prophets -- remember?
Move.
You promised Jadzia you'd make    things right. Well, now's your    chance --
Open the box.
No!
Show yourselves. I've come to    speak with you...
Do we stand down, colonel?
Sir -- we're getting a    transmission from Deep Space    Nine. The wormhole... it's back.
On screen.
(still awaiting an     answer)    Nerys?
Open a channel to all Bajoran    ships.        Hold your position and prepare to    fire on my command.
I'm afraid the colonel has run   out of time.
Lock targets.
Targets locked.
Still glad you came along?
I wouldn't have missed it for   anything.
Nerys...
They're pulling back.
Colonel... Admiral Ross would   like to speak with you.
Put him through.
You can blink now, colonel.   You've won.       Senator Cretak has agreed to   remove the weapons from Derna.
What changed her mind?
I told her that if she didn't   remove them, I would.
And what changed your mind?
You did, colonel. Remind me   never to play poker with you.
Well, Worf... did I not promise   you a glorious battle?
It is all that I had hoped for.
EM pulse ready, general.
Then what are you waiting for?   Fire!
By all means, Chief. Fire.
It's working.
Great. Now can we leave?
Full impulse.
I hope Jadzia appreciates all    this...
I think she does.
Lohm-Ict-lihj posh-Machh-lodge    Sto-vo-kor... (Open your gates,    Sto-vo-kor... )

Jadzia pay-lodge pah-dock-Lih    Dun. Shoo-vwee-vahm baht-leh pay-   lodge. Pay-lodge Poh-Hokh-Vahd    Sto-vo-kor. (Welcome Jadzia to    your halls... welcome this    honored warrior... welcome her,    Sto-vo-kor, for all eternity.)
The Sisko has completed his task.
Sarah?
The Kosst Amojan no longer    threatens us. All has been    restored.
You mean the Pah-wraith? It's no    longer in the wormhole?
I have cast it out.
Is that why the Prophets sent me    to Tyree? To release you from    the Orb?
The Kosst Amojan tried to stop    you with a false vision. But you    did not waver. You fulfilled    your destiny.
My destiny? You make it sound    like my life's over.
The Sisko must still face many    tasks.
I don't suppose you're going to    tell me what they are...
The Emissary is corporeal.    Linear.
Linear or not, I need some    answers.
The Sisko is intrusive.
Are you Sarah Sisko? Are you my    mother?
Sarah Sisko was corporeal. For a    time, I shared her existence.
You took over her body --    (putting it all     together)    -- made sure she married my    father... so that she'd give    birth to me...
The Sisko is necessary.
And once you didn't need her    anymore, you left her... no    wonder she walked out on my    father. She never chose him, you    did.
The Sisko would prefer different    answers.
What you're telling me isn't easy    to accept... you arranged my    birth. I exist because of you.
The Sisko's path is a difficult    one.
But why me? Why did it have to    be me?
Because it could be no one else.
Benjamin?
That must've been some Orb    experience.
I'll tell you about it...    someday.
Welcome back, captain.
We've missed you, sir.
Thank you -- I knew you'd bring    the Prophets back to us.
I hear you've all been pretty    busy yourselves.
Nerys! Julian! Odo! It's so    good to see you. Worf -- we need    to talk --!
Who's that?
That's Dax.
Dax?
That's right, Ezri Dax.    Incredible, isn't it?
It cannot be...
She's so much... shorter.
Just when you thought things    couldn't get more interesting...
